case_name: Shrimati Arati Ray Choudhury v. Union of India

facts.text: The petitioner, Shrimati Arati Ray Choudhury, is a permanent employee in the South Eastern Railway.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner, Shrimati Arati Ray Chou- dhury, is a permanent employee in the South Eastern Railway- a Government of India Undertaking-which runs two Higher Secondary Schools for girls one at Adra and other at Kharagpur.

facts.text: South Eastern Railway runs two Higher Secondary Schools for girls one at Adra and other at Kharagpur.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner, Shrimati Arati Ray Chou- dhury, is a permanent employee in the South Eastern Railway- a Government of India Undertaking-which runs two Higher Secondary Schools for girls one at Adra and other at Kharagpur.

facts.text: Vacancy in the post of the Headmistress of the Kharagpur school arose.

anchor.surface_text: Broadly stated, the question which we have to decide in this petition under article 32 of the Constitution is whether the vacancy in the post of the Headmistress of the Kharagpur school can be treated as being reserved for a Scheduled Caste candidate

facts.text: Petitioner contends the vacancy is open to all candidates.

anchor.surface_text: ...can be treated as being reserved for a Scheduled Caste candidate, a question which depends for its decision both on the interpretation and the validity of the Carry forward rule. The petitioner assails that rule and contends that the vacancy is open to all candidates while respondent No. 8, who belongs to Scheduled Caste, contends for a contrary position.

facts.text: Respondent No. 8 belongs to Scheduled Caste and contends vacancy reserved.

anchor.surface_text: ...can be treated as being reserved for a Scheduled Caste candidate, a question which depends for its decision both on the interpretation and the validity of the Carry forward rule. The petitioner assails that rule and contends that the vacancy is open to all candidates while respondent No. 8, who belongs to Scheduled Caste, contends for a contrary position.

facts.text: In August 1966, a vacancy arose in the post of the Headmistress of the Adra school and was filled up on the footing that it was unreserved.

anchor.surface_text: In August 1966, a vacancy arose in the post of the Headmistress of the Adra school and was filled up on the footing that it was unreserved.

facts.text: Headmistress of the Kharagpur school was due to retire with effect from January 1, 1969.

anchor.surface_text: The Headmistress of the Kharagpur school was due to retire with effect from January 1, 1969 and therefore on December 5, 1968 the Railway administration formed a panel of candidates for selection to that post

facts.text: On December 5, 1968 the Railway administration formed a panel of candidates for selection to Headmistress Kharagpur post and fixed December 18, 1968 as the date for holding interviews.

anchor.surface_text: ...and therefore on December 5, 1968 the Railway administration formed a panel of candidates for selection to that post and fixed December 18, 1968 as the date for holding interviews.

facts.text: Names of four Assistant Mistresses called for selection, arranged in the panel seniority-wise, the petitioner occupying the top place and respondent No. 8 the third place.

anchor.surface_text: The names of four Assistant Mistresses called for selection, were arranged in the panel seniority- wise, the petitioner occupying the top place and respondent No. 8 the third place.

facts.text: Meeting of December 18, 1968 stayed by Calcutta High Court in Writ Petition Civil Rule No. 2117W of 1968 brought by respondent No. 8 for readjustment of her seniority.

anchor.surface_text: The meeting of the 18th was stayed by the Calcutta High Court in a Writ Petition  Civil Rule No. 2117W of 1968  brought by respondent No. 8 for readjustment of her seniority.

facts.text: On December 28, 1968 the petitioner was asked to take over charge of the post.

anchor.surface_text: On December 28. 1969 the petitioner was asked to take over charge of the post and on January 4. 1969 she was promoted to officiate as a Headmistress, purely on local stop-gap basis,...

facts.text: On January 4, 1969 petitioner was promoted to officiate as Headmistress on local stop-gap basis, no right or title to the post.

anchor.surface_text: ...On December 28. 1969 the petitioner was asked to take over charge of the post and on January 4. 1969 she was promoted to officiate as a Headmistress, purely on local stop-gap basis, and on the express condition that the promotion will not confer upon her any right or title to the Post.

facts.text: Respondent No. 8 filed Writ Petition Civil Rule No. 499 W of 1969 asking that the notice of December 5, 1968 be quashed as vacancy reserved for Scheduled Caste candidate.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 8 then filed another Writ Petition in the Calcutta High Court  Civil Rule No. 499 W  of 1969  asking that the notice of December 5, 1968 be quashed as the vacancy in the post of the Headmistress of the Kharagpur school ought under the relevant rules, to be treated as being reserved for a Schedule Caste candidate.

facts.text: On April 15, 1969 Railway administration issued fresh notice fixing interviews on April 29 after stay in 2117 vacated.

anchor.surface_text: In the meanwhile, the stay order issued in Writ Petition 2117 of 1968 was vacated by the High Court and therefore on April 15, 1969 the Railway administration issued a fresh notice fixing the interviews of the four candidates on April 29.

facts.text: Respondent No. 8 obtained injunction in Writ Petition 499 of 1969 restraining interviews.

anchor.surface_text: This attempt also proved abortive as respondent No. 8 obtained in Writ Petition 499 of 1969 an injunction restraining the authorities from holding the interviews.

facts.text: On December 24, 1970 a learned single Judge of Calcutta High Court allowed Writ Petition 499 of 1969, holding post reserved for Scheduled Caste and respondent No. 8 alone entitled.

anchor.surface_text: On December 24, 1970 a learned single Judge of the Calcutta High Court allowed Writ Petition 499 of 1969, holding that the post in question must be treated as being reserved, for a Scheduled Caste candidate and that therefore respondent No. 8 was alone entitled to appear before the selection Board for her appointment as Headmistress of the said Girls school.

facts.text: Petitioner and two other candidates not impleaded in Writ Petition 499 of 1969.

anchor.surface_text: Neither the petitioner nor the two other candidates were impleaded to this petition.

facts.text: Appeal No. 454 of 1971 from single judge judgment dismissed by Division Bench on September 14, 1971.

anchor.surface_text: These respondents carried an appeal  No. 454 of 1971  from the judgment of the learned single Judge but it was dismissed by a Division Bench on September 14, 1971.

facts.text: On November 6, 1971 Chief Personnel Officer of S.E. Railway issued Memorandum to hold selection for panel of 2: one reserved SC existing vacancy, one unreserved unforeseen.

anchor.surface_text: On November 6, 1971 the Chief Personnel Officer of the S. E. Railway issued a Memorandum stating that it was decided to hold a selection to draw up a panel of 2 approved candidates to fill the post of Headmistress, one post being reserved for the scheduled caste against the existing vacancy and another to cover unforeseen requirement-unreserved.

facts.text: Petitioner filed Writ Petition Civil Rule No. 1395W of 1972 challenging the memorandum, injunction granted February 11, 1972.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner filed a writ petition  Civil Rule No. 1395W of 1972  in the Calcutta High Court to challenge the memorandum and ... On February 11, 1972, a learned single Judge granted an injunction in that writ petition restraining the Railway administration from making any appointment on the basis of the memorandum of November 6, 1971.

facts.text: On March 21, 1973 Chief Personnel Officer ordered respondent No. 8 posted as Headmistress Kharagpur subject to conditions.

anchor.surface_text: The Chief Personnel Officer, thereafter, passed an order on March 21, 1973 that respondent No. 8 be posted immediately as the Headmistress of the Kharagpur school, subject to certain conditions.

facts.text: Adra vacancy filled August 16, 1966 by Smt. Gita Biswas, senior most Assistant Mistress, treated as unreserved though roster point 1 reserved.

anchor.surface_text: The vacancy at Adra was filled on August 16, 1966 by the appointment of the senior most Assistant Mistress, Smt. Gita Biswas. In pursuance of the Memorandum dated December 4, 1963 of the Ministry of Home Affairs, the Railway Board revised the model roster by their letter of January 16, 1964. The first point in this roster is a reserved point and therefore the Adra vacancy was strictly a reserved vacancy.

facts.text: Kharagpur vacancy occurred in financial year 1968-69 by retirement of Smt. Bina Devi effective December 31, 1968.

anchor.surface_text: The vacancy in the post of the Headmistress of the Kharagpur school occurred in the financial year 1968-69 by the, retirement of Smt. Bina Devi with effect from December 31, 1968.

facts.text: Respondent No. 8 is the only candidate belonging to scheduled caste among the 4 Assistant Mistresses.

anchor.surface_text: This vacancy, indubitably, had to be treated as a reserved vacancy and since from amongst the 4 Assistant Mistresses, respondent No. 8 was the only candidate belonging to the scheduled caste, she was entitled to be considered for selection to the post of the Headmistress, to the exclusion of the other 3.

facts.text: Petitioner does not belong to reserved class.

anchor.surface_text: ...to the exclusion of the other 3. The claims, if any, of the petitioner who is not a reserved candidate have to be postponed,...

Under article 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforcement of fundamental rights. Purshottam Chatterjee and Rathin Das, for the petitioner. S. Nariman, Additional Solicitor General and M. N. Shroff for respondents Nos. 1-5. N.

anchor.surface_text: the Railway Board by its letter of January 16, 1964 prepared a new Model Roster signifying the turns of reserved and unreserved vacancies. Under this Roster 12.5 per cent of the vacancies were reserved for scheduled castes and 5 per cent for the scheduled tribes. The Roster runs thus Point on the Roster Whether Unreserved or Reserved for 1 Scheduled Castes 2-3 Unreserved 4 Scheduled Tribe 5-8 Unreserved

anchor.surface_text: The Note appended to the Rule defines a Recruitment year as a calendar year and says that for purposes of the two year limit for the carry forward of reserved vacancies, recruitment year shall mean the year in which recruitment is actually made. By a letter dated October 6, 1964 of the Railway Board, this Note was modified in its application to the Railway Services to the extent that Recruitment year was to be the financial year and not the calendar year.

concepts.interpretation: For Railways, recruitment year means financial year

anchor.surface_text: in this petition under article 32 of the Constitution is whether the vacancy in the post of the Headmistress of the Kharagpur school can be treated as being reserved for a Scheduled Caste candidate, a question which depends for its decision both on the interpretation and the validity of the Carry forward rule. anchor.surface_text: That takes us to the merits of the challenge made by the petitioner to the Rules providing for reservation of posts for scheduled castes and scheduled tribes. The contention is that on a true interpretation of the Rules, the vacancy in the post of the Headmistress of the Kharagpur school ought to be treated as an unreserved vacancy and secondly that the Carry forward provision of the rules is violative of articles 14 and 16 of the Constitution

The State of Madhya Pradesh 1  that, except for good reasons the practice of approaching the Supreme Court directly under article 32 in matters which have been taken to the High Court and found against, without obtaining leave to appeal therefrom, is number to be encouraged.

anchor.surface_text: In M. R. Balaji and Ors. v. State of Mysore  1  this Court struck down as uncontitutional an order by which 68 per cent of the Seats in educational institutions were reserved for scheduled castes, scheduled tribes and the other educationally and socially backward classes.

precedents.case_name: M R Balaji v State of Mysore
precedents.cited_proposition: struck down 68% reservation as unconstitutional; reservation should generally be less than 50%
precedents.cited_holding: 68 per cent of the Seats in educational institutions were reserved ... struck down as uncontitutional

anchor.surface_text: Following this decision, the majority observed in Devadasans case that in order to effectuate the guarantee companytained in article 16 1 , each year of recruitment has to be companysidered separately by itself for, the reservation for backward companymunities should number be so excessive as to create a monopoly

precedents.cited_proposition: each year of recruitment has to be considered separately; reservation should not be so excessive as to create a monopoly

anchor.surface_text: The decision in Devadasans case was rended on August 29, 1963 and on December 4, 1963 the Ministry of Home Affairs issued a memorandum modifying the Carry forward rule so as to companyply with the decision.

anchor.surface_text: in this petition under article 32 of the Constitution is whether the vacancy in the post of the Headmistress of the Kharagpur school can be treated as being reserved for a Scheduled Caste candidate, a question which depends for its decision both on the interpretation and the validity of the Carry forward rule.

This vacancy, indubitably, had to be treated as a reserved vacancy and since from amongst the 4 Assistant Mistresses, respondent No. 8 was the only candidate belonging to the scheduled caste, she was entitled to be considered for selection to the post of the Headmistress, to the exclusion of the other 3.

anchor.surface_text: That takes us to the merits of the challenge made by the petitioner to the Rules providing for reservation of posts for scheduled castes and scheduled tribes.
